Nicklous Smith purchased a mobile home from Clayton Homes in Louisa, KY. After installation, the contractor improperly set up the HVAC system without a P-trap, causing humidity issues, standing water, and mold growth.

By July 2025, Nicklous discovered water pooling inside the air handler near the breaker. 2 licensed HVAC technicians confirmed the unit was oversized (3-ton instead of 2.5-ton), leading to moisture buildup, water in the underbelly, and likely mold-contaminated insulation and ductwork.

Nicklous contacted Clayton Homes, HomeFirst (extended warranty), and Kentucky Farm Bureau:

Clayton Homes offered partial repairs (air handler, ducts, insulation) but not full remediation.

HomeFirst is the extended warranty company which denied coverage, claiming it wasn’t a covered defect. Farm Bureau was notified but elected not to file a claim with them, they insisted on getting HomeFirst or Clayton Homes to provide coverage.

DIY mold tests came back positive, though Clayton refused action pending lab confirmation.

No payments or repairs have been made. Nicklous and his wife Lindsey Smith seek legal help to pursue Clayton Homes and others for defective installation, property damage, and mold contamination

Laura Hanson called to discuss significant issues with her homeowner’s insurance claim involving extensive repair costs, living expense disputes, and ongoing delays. She stated the insurer stopped paying for repairs, citing a national average rebuild cost of approximately $180 per square foot, despite no such limitation appearing in her policy and her actual repair costs being nearly three times that amount. Laura emphasized that no major upgrades were made and that the insurer has provided misleading and inconsistent information throughout the claim process.

Laura also reported serious problems with Additional Living Expenses (ALE), including being directed to use expensive Airbnb housing (approximately $10,000 per month) while being initially prohibited from using far less expensive apartment alternatives. She later learned the apartment option should have been allowed. She described repeated delays, including a three-and-a-half-month delay just to receive the correct link to submit personal property claims, raising concerns about missed deadlines. Laura estimates the policy provided approximately $182,000 in dwelling coverage, that she has exceeded that amount, and that the insurer may still owe approximately $70,000, in addition to other disputed expenses. Overall, the family reports being out hundreds of thousands of dollars.

Hello,

I have been dealing with the insurance company since my home was surrounded in water and damaged during the February 2025 flood. The damage is substantial, obvious, and legitimate, as evidenced by contractors and even the claims adjuster (multiple times over the phone and in person - off record, of course). Yet, I’ve been met with resistance at every turn.

Upon initial inspection by the claims adjuster on approximately February 21, I received an estimate for damages and then a proof of loss and subsequent check for $3,600.90 (after the deductible). This was to cover damages and cleaning in the crawlspace.

During that initial inspection, the adjuster found that my home had also sustained structural damage. He made the recommendation to go ahead and file an initial claim and then the insurance company would hire a structural engineer to survey the additional damages. He actually stated on several occasions that he personally felt that I would receive policy limit and that m my house could probably be condemned as he didn’t see how it would withstand another flood event due to the significant structural damage, especially to the foundation and pier and weight bearing supports. So, we proceeded with the structural engineer.

The structural engineer’s report made several false claims about pre-existing damage, but he also contradicted his claims multiple times throughout the report. The insurance company only acknowledged the damage claimed to be pre-existing and I was denied any compensation and my claim was closed.

After much conversation and ultimately submitting a formal request, as well as a copy of the engineer’s report with the admission and documentation of damage that was caused by the current flooding marked and noted with a highlighter, the insurance company finally agreed to reopen my claim on June 2, more than 3 months after the flood, and asked that I submit an estimate for repairs from a licensed contractor, which I did.

The estimate to repair only the damage caused by the flooding that is allowable and eligible for compensation, as defined in the flood policy, was $133,688. I was told by the contractor that the cost to repair all damage from the flood would actually be twice that amount and cost more than just tearing down my house and rebuilding. I did not submit that estimate because I understood how the policy was written and any damage caused by earth movement or soil erosion is not covered, as the policy is a single-peril policy that only pays for covered damage due to direct physical loss by or from flood (II.C.14), not as a result of the flood waters moving the foundation and in turn, causing structural damage.

So, I agreed with the adjuster and insurance company to only submit damages caused by direct contact with water, which is what I did. Since that date, I have been met with nothing but stress and aggravation, and have pleaded my case nearly daily to someone in the group of those involved, all to no avail. I understand the flood policy is written with many exclusions as to structural damage, but the damage I am requesting to be compensated for is completely legitimate and meets the requirements of the policy.

Although it seems like a simple, cut and dry claim, I just can’t get anyone to read (or care) enough to understand. Then on June 25, more than 4 months since the flood, I finally received a proof of loss for the structural damage. With estimates for more than $133,000 and a policy limit of $120,000, I was offered an additional $1,281.69 for damages ($4,882.59 total with the initial claim) and was told if I wasn’t satisfied to appeal it.

I have researched and read nearly every appeal decision and memo available on the FEMA website and I’m fairly confident that if I appeal to FEMA, it will simply result in a loss of time and effort on my part, as FEMA simply concurs with the insurance company’s decision in nearly all similar cases. This is a well-known fact. Therefore, I would like to pursue litigation and file suit against the insurer and/or FEMA, if possible, as I see no other reasonable recourse.

The claims adjuster is asking that I sign the proof of loss and assuring me that doing so is not stating that I agree with the amount, nor will it forfeit my right to appeal. However, I have been lied to so many times since this started in February, that I want to make certain before signing.

Also, at the bottom of the Proof of Loss, it states, “I understand that I must submit a Proof of Loss within 60 days of the date of the loss or within any extension of that deadline made in writing by FEMA's Federal Insurance Administrator.”

The date of loss listed on the Proof of Loss is February 15, 2025, well past the 60 day deadline and there is no other date or note of an extension. I have not signed because I’m just not sure if I should or not.

I have all emails, reports, documentation, photos, etc. printed and organized date. I also have everything saved in .pdf and .jpg format and uploaded to my online Google drive for which I can provide a link. Many of the emails are replies, so need to be read from the bottom up, or last page to first, within each dated file.

I am in the Pikeville, KY area, but will be traveling though Lexington this Thursday, July 31 and could bring all printed documents to you and sign any required paperwork if you think I have a case and are willing to accept it.

I appreciate your time and consideration and look forward to hearing from you.

Sincerely,

Eric T. Compton
(606) 616-2978

additionalinformation:
Client reports roof damage likely caused by wind in early March 2025, while she and her husband were in Florida and is disputing Stillwater Insurance’s assignment of the loss date—which increased her deductible and reduced payment—seeking legal help for a potential bad faith insurance claim.

Homeowner Elizabeth Fox experienced roof damage at her Prospect, KY property while she was away in Florida. After returning on May 8, 2025, she discovered a shingle on the ground, and her roofer later confirmed storm damage likely occurred in early March 2025. When she filed a claim with Stillwater Insurance on June 12, 2024, the company recorded the date of loss as May 15–16, 2025, after her deductible had increased from $2,500 to $12,680 on April 21, 2025. Despite a $19,600 roof replacement estimate, Stillwater only issued a $550 payment and closed the claim. Mrs. Fox filed a complaint with the Kentucky Department of Insurance, which partially ruled in her favor, but the dispute over the date of loss and deductible remains unresolved. She seeks legal representation for a potential property damage and insurance bad faith claim.






Elizabeth Fox called to follow up on her ongoing homeowners insurance dispute and stated she is now ready to involve a law firm. The Kentucky Department of Insurance advised her that the remaining issue in her claim is factual in nature, which they cannot resolve.

The claim involves roof damage at her home in Norton Commons (Prospect, KY). Elizabeth and her husband returned from Florida in early May 2025 and noticed a loose shingle on the ground. A roofer inspected the roof on June 12, 2025, confirmed the shingle came from her roof, and identified additional missing shingles. A claim was reported that same day.

At issue is the date of loss. Stillwater Insurance recorded the date as May 15–16, 2025, which placed the loss after a significant deductible increase that went into effect on April 21, 2025. Elizabeth disputes this and states she reported that the damage occurred before May 8, 2025, when they returned home. She believes the insurer intentionally pushed the date forward to apply the higher deductible.

Stillwater initially denied the claim due to the deductible exceeding their damage estimate. Elizabeth’s roofer determined the shingles could not be reasonably matched, which under Kentucky law requires full roof replacement. After Elizabeth filed a complaint with the Kentucky Department of Insurance, Stillwater ultimately agreed to replace the roof but calculated payment in a way that left Elizabeth with only about $500 after applying the increased deductible to a roughly $19,000 roof replacement. She has not cashed the check.
projectName: Fox, Elizabeth et al. v. Stillwater

additionalinformation:
Michael Gentry experienced a major water loss on June 8, 2024, when a pipe burst in his home, causing significant flooding. He filed a homeowner’s insurance claim with Home Site Insurance.
The mitigation company, ServiceMaster, allegedly performed poor work that left moisture in the HVAC system, leading to additional rust and damage throughout the home.

Mr. Gentry filed a claim with Home Site, but he reports receiving a low settlement offer and facing numerous delays. The initial payment was held by the mortgage company for 45 days before he could access any funds. Over the past year and a half, he has been bounced between more than eight different adjusters, each requesting duplicate documentation. Home Site has paid approximately $114,000 toward repairs, but they are now refusing to release additional funds until Mr. Gentry provides further proof of how all prior payments were spent.

The home remains unfinished, with the kitchen and master bathroom still needing repairs estimated at $30,000–$40,000. Mr. Gentry has also exceeded his temporary housing coverage since February 2025 and is now more than $40,000 out of pocket. He believes the insurer is acting in bad faith by delaying the process and forcing him to repeatedly resubmit information.

Mr. Gentry would like to pursue legal action or otherwise obtain guidance on his options. He mentioned being told that he may be unable to sue until the claim is formally denied and that his policy may include a one-year limitation period. He is also concerned about ServiceMaster’s potential liability for poor mitigation work. I was informed by the agent handling the case on November 13th that they are sending me a proof of loss document and I have 60 days to fill it out. I feel like I'm being accused of something and that they're just turning everything around on me. Adding stress and damage to what has already been one of the most uncomfortable situations I've ever dealt with in my life. This was worse than my divorce. It has become so straining that we are literally at the point of trying to just sell the home and get out of it it is just left a bad taste in our mouth that I don't believe we can recover from.

The drainage ditch next to my house filled up over 6 feet and crossed the street next to my house, at the same time it breached the water retention wall around my walk out basement, busted down the door, and filled my house with 8.5 feet of water in less than 10 minutes. I do not live in a flood zone or near any water (pond, river, lake etc). Our house is unlivable as the breaker box was fully submerged, our bedroom and son’s bedroom were full to the ceiling of water for over 24 hours and the AC was fully submerged in water and no longer works. At the time this occurred, our contractor who finished our basement 2 years ago watched Hopkinsville Water Environment Authority
change out a quarry pump at the end of my road. They are still denying responsibility. Homeowner’s insurance claim – property damage from April 2024 storms (lightning, wind, and water intrusion). Underpayment and mishandling of an insurance claim.

Client is seeking legal assistance regarding an unresolved homeowner’s insurance claim with State Farm following severe storms in early April 2024 that caused lightning, wind, and water damage to her home and garage. The garage, which was used for storage, contained a significant amount of personal property valued at approximately $72,000, including items from her former boutique business and important legal documents. Despite extensive damage, State Farm has only made partial payments totaling about $15,000 and has provided inconsistent explanations for why much of her property was not covered. The company delayed assigning an adjuster until late April and did not inspect the property until mid-May, by which time the damage had worsened. Tiffany reports that she has dealt with multiple adjusters, conflicting information, and coverage errors, such as payments marked for repairs that were never completed. She believes State Farm failed to properly apply the “storm-created opening” clause in her policy and did not honor a verbal assurance made by a section manager in June that her claim would be fully paid. Tiffany estimates her total losses at around $100,000 to $130,000 and is now seeking legal help to recover the remaining unpaid amounts for her property, electrical work, and home repairs.

The loss occurred around October 22, 2025, when Brandon’s ex-girlfriend and her new partner, who were living in the home at the time, intentionally damaged the property prior to vacating. Damage included flooding and the removal of the hot water heater, which was later ripped out again after the claim was initially filed.

The insurance carrier, HomeLight, inspected the property shortly after the claim was submitted and initially indicated no issues. However, after months of inactivity and lack of communication, Brandon filed a Department of Insurance complaint, which prompted contact from a supervisor.

The carrier has since shifted denial reasons multiple times, ultimately citing a vacancy exclusion, despite Brandon having proof the property was occupied at the time of loss. The adjuster has stated a denial letter was sent but has refused to confirm the mailing address, date sent, or provide proof of delivery, raising concerns it may have been sent to the damaged Kentucky property instead of Brandon’s Michigan address.

Estimated damages are approximately $50,000, though no formal repair estimate has been completed yet. Brandon reports extensive documentation and correspondence supporting his position and was advised to email all records to the firm for attorney review.

Dakota Smith called Denham Property & Injury Law Firm seeking a consultation regarding a potential bad-faith homeowners insurance claim. He explained that after filing a claim on September 25, 2025, for water damage caused by an attic window A/C unit discharging water, his insurance company denied the claim despite having received professional reports from Servpro and an HVAC technician confirming the source of the damage. The adjuster spent only about 20 minutes inspecting the property, performed no testing, and was caught on security footage admitting uncertainty, yet still issued a denial without citing policy language. After Dakota’s family attorney intervened, the insurer reopened the claim and is now sending an engineer for reinspection. No repairs have been made, no payments issued, and Servpro withheld an estimate due to potential asbestos in attic tiles.


Estimate cost of repairs $15,000 - $20,000

A plumber inspected the property, confirmed no additional leaks, and reportedly told the adjuster no further information was needed. Despite this, State Farm denied the claim twice, citing alleged conflicts in the plumbing report and characterizing the damage as pre-existing or the home as a rental—both of which Britney disputes.

Misty has been displaced for over two months and is currently living in a camper in the driveway due to the home being uninhabitable. There are ongoing issues with incorrect policy information, including an outdated primary residence, the policy still being tied to Misty’s deceased husband, and incorrect contact details, which has prevented access to policy documents and claim correspondence.

Britney has sent multiple unanswered emails to State Farm and is seeking assistance due to lack of communication and clarity. Eliza confirmed contact information, requested all prior correspondence and documentation, and advised she would review the matter with an attorney and follow up with next steps by the end of the day or the following day.

Curtis Foote, of Crestwood, KY, filed a homeowner’s claim with Erie Insurance in April 2025 after a March–April 2025 storm caused roof leaks and hail damage. His roofer and two additional companies confirmed significant hail damage requiring full roof replacement.

Erie’s adjuster acknowledged some damage but approved only $4,858.18 for minor repairs (vents, skylight, gutters, screens) and denied roof replacement. Curtis did not deposit the check. Erie later sent an engineer who supported their denial, despite multiple contractors finding hail damage.

Curtis filed a complaint with the Kentucky Insurance Commissioner, who found no regulatory violations. He has since replaced the roof at his own cost (~$32,000) and believes Erie’s actions may constitute bad faith.
Wants to go after Erie Insurance for wrongfully denying and undervaluing his hail damage claim

Stephanie is seeking representation related to a complex property damage and insurance bad-faith dispute involving her primary residence and resulting loss of her home investment. She reports a prolonged and escalating breakdown in how her claim was handled, which she believes constitutes insurance bad faith and potentially improper conduct by multiple involved parties, including the insurer and associated or “preferred” vendors.

Stephanie stated that she timely reported the loss and has consistently cooperated by providing extensive documentation, records, communications, and supporting materials. Despite this, she alleges the insurer and related entities have repeatedly delayed, deflected responsibility, and failed to resolve the claim, resulting in worsening property conditions and significant financial loss. She indicated that rather than progressing toward repair or payment, the situation has continued to deteriorate over time.

She described a pattern in which she was asked for additional information repeatedly, complied each time, and was then met with further requests or inaction, creating a cycle of delay. Stephanie believes this conduct was intentional and designed to wear her down or cause her to miss critical deadlines. She specifically referenced looming deadlines that now place her rights at risk if immediate legal action is not taken.

Stephanie reports that the property issues ultimately resulted in her losing her entire home investment, causing substantial financial harm and emotional distress. She believes the insurer failed to properly investigate the claim, failed to act in good faith, and failed to fairly evaluate coverage. She also expressed concerns that third parties involved in the claim process, including vendors connected to the insurer, contributed to or exacerbated the damage and delays.

Michael reports repeated attempts to have the solar company (Solgan Solar) return to repair the damage, but despite scheduling appointments and taking time off work, the company repeatedly fails to show up or follow through. As a result, the water intrusion has continued to worsen and is now causing significant interior damage, including floor buckling, damage in the bathroom and utility room, and water intrusion spreading toward the center of the home. Michael’s homeowners insurance (State Farm) declined coverage, stating the damage is related to the solar panel installation. He has not received any repair estimates and is increasingly concerned as the condition of his previously well-maintained home continues to deteriorate.
